>>3830005
Also on the point of retconning, I would be remiss to ignore the tone shift of the manga as a whole. Shizuka was written in the context of a blatant ecchi manga so her behaviors were not written with her future character flaws in mind; all that is retroactive. Even Mio was just a single target horndog initially as well. That's the reason their tasteful sex scene is utterly different from all of the previous sexual content. It's far more about the emotional development of the characters rather than the erotica. The fact that it accomplished this without any dialogue is a testament to the strength of the identity of the characters and the visual storytelling, despite the shift in narrative partway through.

>>3829389
That's completely justified and a valid opinion. I think that part of it is that Overlady is super fun but TtS just isn't, really. Scratch at the paint a bit and it's almost proper grimdark. May Sappho forgive me for uttering this word, a deconstruction of the magical girl concept with the resulting pieces taken to their logical extremes.

A dystopia masquerading as a utopia. Broken people pretending to be capable leaders. Magical girls who took over the world to stop their own from suffering, only for the girls to end up on the frontlines of a hopeless intetstellar war. A goddess who peddles hope and salvation, but at what cost? A former disciple willing to sacrifice anything and anyone to thwart the divine plan and save the goddess from her fate.

It is rather heavy under the surface. Almost joyless and uncompromising.
>here's a scene of an endless number of lifeless girls floting in cloning tubes in a government facility since all of the magical girls are probably soulless zombies animated by pseudomagical means, enjoy that mental image in this story about silly magical girl lesbians

I'm a sucker for this kind of high quality and somewhat angsty stuff so I'm loving the ride and letting my imagination run wild. It's so good. But it is probably not for everyone, I feel.

last_replies.com:
TtS actually delivers its weird scifi thing I had been waiting for for a long time since I smelled it years ago, but along the way I can't help but feel it really took its time to get there.

Then there's also the fact that there are a few things in there that are really funny but not in a way the author may have wanted. At some point they talk about the possibility of bringing back capitalism to boost industrial output, while actual nations that manage to boost it during actual wars do it by heavy-handed, ruthless central control, be it WW2 USSR or WW2 USA, there's the bit about mr diesfast naming his v2 Rommel while actual Rommel is only good at his thing in hagiographies, in reality he performed well as a tactical officer, did war crimes in the France campaign, bounced around a bit, and then got suckered in overextending and attacking a position held by three times as many troops as he had, except they were rested and in good supply unlike his, by fucking Auchinleck of all people, which speaks of his operational and strategic skill, he was aiming to reconnect with German forces in Ukraine through the Caucasus. Yeah.

On the other hand there's the hilarity of Eliezer Yudkowski clearly reading it and copying wholesale the concept of Governance, that Hieronym got from actual scifi that he opened named.
That's enough bitching though, what I really enjoy is that it was clearly planned out and that you can get pay-offs from the set-ups instead of just flailing about trying to get something out like in the average million word long fic.

>>3829892
I felt sort of similar things at times. The wehraboo thing is just quaint and common among weebs while the commie-cap dichotomy felt weird. A scarcity-postscarcity divide would have made more sense. Would have worked well to explain how some colonies weren't yet at the sufficient infrastructure levels to sustain a post-scarcity society and had to resort to some sort of economic system of supply-demand for efficient resources&goods distribution. Could also be used to explain the need for a shift within the core world where the demands of the warmachine will have finally started to impede on the post-scarcity needs in certain areas and requires a step down so that the now again limited resources could be allocated to the ever growing warmachine. The system could be anything from a capitalist one (provide easy credit to MIC who can then outbid everyone else) or a command one (just allocate the needs of the MIC before the rest of the economy and let the latter be a hippie commune of equally shared resources for all you care). A simplistic commie good cap bad differentiation feels banal in an otherwise sophisticated story. I can see the intent but the parlance makes it weird.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3830603
A lot of the quality depends on the publisher.
Amazon does cap the resolution at x1920 but that's not relevant when the original is x1200.
Old releases will also get stuck in lower quality even when the publisher switched to higher resolutions with newer releases.
There's also a disparity between magazines and tankobons. For some publishers the tankobon have better quality but in a few cases the magazines are better.
See the posts above for the special case of Houbunsha's 4koma series.

If you care about ripping your ebooks then Kobo is an easy option since there's publicly available tools.
Otherwise Bookwalker is going to give the same quality at a lower price.

Got around to watching the movie, but what was even the point of it? Two hours of mundane adult lives, showcasing how the distance between the girls has only grown since their school days.
Nevermind the lack of yuri, it wasn't even comfy.
Can't believe this is from the same studio that put together such a pleasant first season, framed as a girl meets girl story, but the second one should've disillusioned me in retrospect.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3828784
CGDCT only works when the focus is on the cute girls and their relationships, the cute things they do should be just a pretext for them to interact.
If I had to summarize season 1 in a sentence it would be:
>Two very different girls have a fateful meeting, and as they grow closer they gradually learn from each other and broaden their horizons while doing comfy camping activities with their friends or on their own.
I could use similar sentences to describe other good anime like Yama no Susume or Super Cub.
As for the movie:
>The girls have moved on with their lives and are doing their best at being functioning members of society, but at some point they also decide to get together during weekends to build a camping ground as a pet project, and face many related challenges.
You can immediately tell which one has the makings of an interesting story and which one is just bland, and I would probably use a similar sentence for season 2 if I hadn't completely forgotten it on account of being entirely unmemorable. Either the first season was a fluke, or something's changed within the staff/production, I have no other explanation.

Officially on halt. I don't doubt that Ningiyau believes she'll come back to it one day, but until then she wants to work on at least one other series that's not SoL. Lot of people seem to think it's Azalea's Cross with demons and violence, but we'll see. It's tough to see your own art quality and standards for it grow over the years while it takes you more and more time to get just one chapter out.
